questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive muscle weakness, especially after repetitive activity. Further evaluation reveals antibodies against muscle-specific kinase (MuSK). Which of the following best describes the mechanism involved in this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Destruction of the myelin sheath around peripheral nerves

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired regulation and maintenance of acetylcholine receptors

options.label: C
options.text: Blockade of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of acetylcholine release from synaptic vesicles

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired regulation and maintenance of acetylcholine receptors
questions.explanation:
Antibody

Target

Effect

Anti-AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors

Blocks transmission & reduces receptors

Anti-MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Disrupts receptor regulation and stability

Medication

Effect

Penicillamine

It may induce a persistent myasthenic syndrome

Aminoglycosides, Quinolones

It can worsen neuromuscular blockade; it must be avoided

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of myasthenia gravis presents to the clinic with worsening symptoms, including difficulty in lifting her arms and shortness of breath. On examination, you notice that her eyelids are drooping, and she has double vision. What is the most significant risk associated with her current condition if not addressed promptly?
questions.explanation:
Affected Muscles

Key Features

Ocular muscles

Mimics central eye movement disorders.

Cogan's lid twitch sign

Upper eyelid rises briefly after looking down for some time.

Shoulder girdle muscles

Difficulty in overhead activities like combing hair.

Respiratory muscles

Weakness may cause respiratory failure and aspiration risks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute muscle weakness, double vision, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of myasthenia gravis and has been experiencing increased fatigue over the past few days. Which of the following clinical features would best help differentiate a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Myasthenic Crisis

Cholinergic Crisis

Cause

Exacerbation of MG

Excessive anticholinesterase use

Symptoms

Severe muscle weakness, respiratory failure

Fasciculations, paralysis, small pupils (Options A & B ruled out)

Other Signs

-

Pallor, sweating, excessive salivation (Option D ruled out)

Diagnosis

Response to edrophonium test (Option C)

Can confirm cholinergic origin

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with symptoms of fluctuating double vision and drooping eyelids that worsen throughout the day. Neurological examination reveals no other muscular involvement. Blood tests confirm the presence of antibodies against muscle-specific kinase (MuSK). What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate high-dose corticosteroids as the first-line treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend immediate thymectomy regardless of symptom severity.

options.label: C
options.text: Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist.

options.label: D
options.text: Advise the patient to undergo regular monitoring without any treatment.

questions.correct_answer: C. Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Common Symptoms

Intermittent ptosis (drooping eyelid that worsens with the day) and diplopia (double vision).

Absence of Other Symptoms

No muscle weakness in other body parts (e.g., chewing, swallowing, limb movement).

Potential for Progression

May progress to generalized MG but has an excellent prognosis if it remains ocular.

Method

Description

Diagnostic Tests

Repetitive nerve stimulation studies: Produces decremental response.

 

Blood tests for AChR and MuSK antibodies.

Treatment Options

Generalized MG:

Drug of choice: Pyridostigmine (Anticholinesterase medications)

If symptoms persist: Steroids & Mycophenolate

 

OcularMyasthenia Gravis:

DOC: Pyridostigmine

If symptoms persist: Immunotherapy

Other Drugs:

  • Glucocorticoids
  • o Mycophenolate
  • o Rituximab
  • o Eculizumab

 

Myasthenia Crisis:

  • Intravenous immunoglobulins
  • Plasmapheresis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, particularly affecting her eyelids and causing double vision. A thorough clinical evaluation and diagnostic testing are performed. Which of the following diagnostic tests would most likely confirm the suspicion of Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Tensilon Test

Administers edrophonium bromide intravenously.

May show transient muscle function improvement; not highly reliable.

Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS)

Specialized nerve conduction study.

Reveals a decremental response in muscle strength with repeated stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Antibody Testing

Detects auto-antibodies related to MG.

Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibodies: Most common, block AChR function.

Muscle-Specific Kinase (MuSK) Antibodies: Disrupt AChR clustering and stabilization.

Thoracic CT Scan

Essential to rule out thymoma, especially in patients with negative AChR antibody tests.

Condition

Description

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)

Muscle weakness, particularly in limbs, due to autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels.

Botulism

Rare illness caused by a bacterial toxin leading to muscle paralysis.

Muscular Dystrophies

Genetic disorders causing progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.

Metabolic Myopathies

Result from defects in muscle cell metabolic pathways, causing weakness and other symptoms.

Drug-Induced Myopathies

Muscle weakness caused by side effects of certain medications, such as statins and corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with weakness in her arms and difficulty in swallowing. The neurologist suspects myasthenia gravis (MG) and considers treatment options. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient to increase acetylcholine activity at the neuromuscular junction?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Common Drug

Management of Side Effects

Prolongs acetylcholine action by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

Pyridostigmine (anticholinesterase)

(Option C)

Diarrhoea and colic controlled with propantheline.

Cholinergic Crisis

Symptoms

Distinction Method

Overdose of anticholinesterase drugs

Muscle fasciculation, paralysis, pallor, sweating, excessive salivation, constricted pupils.

Clinical features or small doses of edrophonium.

Treatment

Mechanism

Use Case

Intravenous Immunoglobulin

(Option D ruled out)

Rapidly reduces weakness by lowering antibody production.

Acute symptom relief.

Plasma Exchange

Removes antibodies from the blood for a brief marked improvement.

Myasthenic crisis or pre-operative preparation.

Treatment

Dosage/Administration

Notes

Glucocorticoid Treatment

(Option B ruled out)

Varies; initiated in the hospital.

Improves symptoms but may precede exacerbation; long-term use carries risks.

Azathioprine

2.5 mg/kg daily

Reduces glucocorticoid dosage; effects may be delayed for months.

Mycophenolate Mofetil

Less commonly used

Another immunosuppression option.

Thymectomy

Consider for patients <45 years old with symptoms beyond extraocular muscles.

Pending clinical trial confirmation of efficacy.

Prognosis Factor

Outcomes

Variability

Remissions may occur spontaneously.

Ocular Myasthenia

Excellent prognosis with minimal disability.

Young Females with Generalised Disease

May benefit from thymectomy.

Older Patients

Less likely to experience remission, even with treatment.

Disease Progression

Rapid progression is uncommon more than 5 years after onset.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with known myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress. He is diagnosed with a myasthenic crisis. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for immediate management of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Life-threatening condition due to muscle weakness affecting breathing, leading to respiratory failure.

Triggers
  • Infection
  • Surgery
  • Stress
  • Certain medications

Treatment

Purpose

Details

Respiratory Support

Ensure adequate breathing.

May involve providing oxygen or mechanical ventilation.

Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIg)

Reduce harmful antibody levels.

Helps improve muscle strength by lowering antibodies in the blood.

Plasma Exchange (PLEX)

(Option D ruled out)

Remove harmful antibodies from blood.

Similar to IVIg; generally used when IVIg is ineffective or cannot be tolerated.

Corticosteroids

(Option A ruled out)

Suppress the immune system.

Can improve symptoms but may have significant side effects.

Immunosuppressants

(Option C ruled out)

Suppress the immune response.

Options include azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil, which help manage the condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness, dry mouth, and absent tendon reflexes. He has a history of smoking. Electrophysiological testing reveals post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

A condition causing muscle weakness due to impaired transmission across the neuromuscular junction, similar to myasthenia gravis.

Types
  • Inflammatory
  • Paraneoplastic (associated with underlying malignancies, particularly small-cell lung cancer).

Pathophysiology

Antibodies to presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair transmitter release, unlike myasthenia gravis, which involves antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors.

Symptoms
  • Muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth)

Key Clinical Sign

Absence of tendon reflexes, which may return after sustained contraction of the affected muscle.

Diagnostic Testing

Electrophysiological testing showing post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec is indicative of LEMS.

Treatment

Mechanism/Use

3,4-Diaminopyridine

Enhances neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction.

Pyridostigmine

Increases acetylcholine levels, improving neuromuscular transmission.

Immunosuppression

Reduces immune response against voltage-gated calcium channels.

Myasthenia Gravis

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenia Syndrome

   
  • Antibodies to post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors
  • Antibodies to pre-synaptic calcium channels
  • Usually acute or subacute, but can also be chronic.
  • Typically occurs in younger women (20s-30s) or older men (>60s).
  • Gradual onset, often subacute or chronic.
  • Worsens with activity
  • Improves with repetitive use of muscles
  • Decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Rarely associated with cancer
  • Frequently associated with small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is suspected of having myasthenia gravis. The neurologist decides to perform the Tensilon test using edrophonium bromide. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Tensilon test?

options.label: A
options.text: The effects of the test last for about 10 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: It is a highly specific and sensitive test for myasthenia gravis

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle function typically improves within 30 seconds of injection

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous atropine is unnecessary during the procedure

questions.correct_answer: C. Muscle function typically improves within 30 seconds of injection
